body.p: What are the steps of hemostasis?

multiple_choice.choice: platelet aggregation and blood clotting → vasoconstriction
all three steps occur at roughly the same time

response.feedback: Correct. Vasoconstriction increases resistance to blood flow, minimizing blood loss. Platelets aggregate at the site of the injury to temporarily seal the break. Finally, blood clotting uses fibrin to reinforce the “platelet plug”.
Incorrect. Vasoconstriction reduces blood flow and can be triggered relatively quickly. This step happens before the platelets and blood clots can seal the ruptured blood vessel.

Incorrect. Vasoconstriction reduces blood flow and can be triggered relatively quickly. This is therefore the first step of hemostasis. Additionally, before blood clotting begins, platelets must aggregate at the site of the injury to temporarily seal the break. Blood clotting reinforces this “platelet plug” using fibrin.

Incorrect. Vasoconstriction is the first response, functioning to minimize blood flow. Platelet aggregation must occur at the site of injury before blood clotting can reinforce the “platelet plugs” using fibrin threads.
